verses.text: Now concerning the matters you wrote about: It is good for a man not to touch a woman.
verses.comment: Paul responds to questions from Corinth. 'Not to touch a woman' is a euphemism for sexual relations, showing the value of celibacy while not mandating it.

verses.text: But because of sexual immorality, each man should have his own wife, and each woman her own husband.
verses.comment: Marriage is established as the proper context for sexual relations, protecting against immorality and affirming the sanctity of marriage.

verses.text: Let the husband fulfill his duty to his wife, and likewise the wife to her husband.
verses.comment: This mutual obligation underscores the equality and unity within Christian marriage.

verses.text: The wife does not have authority over her own body, but the husband does. Likewise, the husband does not have authority over his own body, but the wife does.
verses.comment: Paul describes profound mutual belonging, emphasizing self-giving love in marriage—a reflection of Christ's love for the Church.

verses.text: Do not deprive one another, except for a time by mutual agreement, so that you may devote yourselves to prayer; then come together again, so that Satan may not tempt you because of your lack of self-control.
verses.comment: Temporary abstinence for prayer points toward the value of spiritual discipline, but always within a supportive marital context.

verses.text: Now I say this as a concession, not as a command.
verses.comment: Paul distinguishes between divine command and pastoral advice—important for wise discernment in Christian living.

verses.text: I wish that all people were as I am. But each has his own gift from God, one person in one way and another in another.
verses.comment: 'Gift from God' (charisma) foreshadows Paul's later teaching on spiritual gifts—both marriage and celibacy are divinely given vocations.

verses.text: Now to the unmarried and to widows I say: It is good for them if they remain as I am.
verses.comment: Paul affirms the value of a single, devoted life, suggesting spiritual benefits and greater freedom for service.

verses.text: But if they cannot exercise self-control, they should marry. For it is better to marry than to burn with passion.
verses.comment: 'Burn with passion' references the power of desire, and marriage is elevated not only as remedy but as a path to holiness.

verses.text: To the married I give this instruction—not I, but the Lord—that a wife should not separate from her husband.
verses.comment: Paul cites Jesus directly; the permanence of marriage is rooted in Christ's own teaching.

verses.text: But if she does depart, she must remain unmarried or be reconciled to her husband—and the husband should not divorce his wife.
verses.comment: The command to remain single or reconcile highlights the sacredness of marriage and upholds the ideal of reconciliation—echoing biblical themes of mercy and restoration.

verses.text: To the rest I say—I, not the Lord—if any brother has a wife who is not a believer, and she is willing to live with him, he should not divorce her.
verses.comment: Paul makes a pastoral judgment for mixed marriages, showing sensitivity to family and evangelistic witness.

verses.text: And if any woman has a husband who is not a believer, and he is willing to live with her, she should not divorce him.
verses.comment: Reciprocity in Paul's advice, emphasizing the role of patience, hope, and example in potentially drawing others to faith.

verses.text: For the unbelieving husband is made holy by his wife, and the unbelieving wife is made holy by her husband. Otherwise your children would be unclean; but as it is, they are holy.
verses.comment: Marital unity sanctifies the household—pointing to the spiritual significance of family rooted in one flesh, prefiguring sacramental realities.

verses.text: But if the unbelieving partner separates, let it be so. In such cases, the brother or sister is not bound. God has called you to peace.
verses.comment: Paul stresses peace as a central Christian value; the Church should foster mercy and understanding in difficult marital situations.

verses.text: For how do you know, wife, whether you will save your husband? Or how do you know, husband, whether you will save your wife?
verses.comment: The witness of believing spouses is powerful; salvation may come through patience and example, which foreshadows the Church's mission of sanctifying the world.

verses.text: Nevertheless, each person should live as the Lord has called him, and in the situation the Lord has assigned. This is my rule in all the churches.
verses.comment: Paul teaches faithfulness to one’s calling. This unity of practice 'in all the churches' suggests apostolic authority and visible unity.

verses.text: Was anyone called while circumcised? He should not become uncircumcised. Was anyone called while uncircumcised? He should not be circumcised.
verses.comment: Paul affirms that cultural or ritual status does not affect one's standing before God; salvation is through Christ alone.

verses.text: Circumcision is nothing and uncircumcision is nothing, but keeping God’s commandments is what matters.
verses.comment: Legal observances are secondary; the priority is obedience and love—fulfilling the law through Christ (see John 14:15).

verses.text: Let each person remain in the situation in which he was called.
verses.comment: God’s calling sanctifies every situation; Christian vocation transcends circumstance.

verses.text: Were you called when a slave? Do not let it trouble you; but if you are able to become free, do so.
verses.comment: Here, Christian dignity is found in Christ, not in social status. Liberation is desirable but not essential for full Christian life.

verses.text: For the one who was called in the Lord as a slave is the Lord’s freedman; likewise, the one who was called as free is Christ's slave.
verses.comment: Christ reverses all earthly positions; spiritual freedom and service are inseparable.

verses.text: You were bought at a price; do not become slaves of men.
verses.comment: 'Bought at a price' is a profound christological reference to Christ’s redeeming sacrifice (see 1 Cor. 6:20), prefigured by Old Testament redemption of Israel.

verses.text: Brothers and sisters, in whatever situation each was called, let him remain with God.
verses.comment: The unity and peace that surpass circumstance reflect trust in God’s providence.

verses.text: Now concerning virgins: I have no command from the Lord, but I give my opinion as one who by the Lord’s mercy is trustworthy.
verses.comment: Paul humbly offers pastoral authority where explicit teaching from Jesus is lacking.

verses.text: Because of the present distress, I think it is good for a person to remain as he is.
verses.comment: 'Present distress' points to persecutions and hardships in the early Christian era, influencing wise, prudent decisions.

verses.text: Are you bound to a wife? Do not seek to be free. Are you free from a wife? Do not seek a wife.
verses.comment: Paul calls for steadfastness and contentment with one's station, echoing Jesus' words about some choosing celibacy for the kingdom.

verses.text: But if you marry, you have not sinned; and if a virgin marries, she has not sinned. Yet those who marry will have troubles in this life, and I want to spare you that.
verses.comment: marriage is a good, holy calling, though it brings real difficulties—Paul advocates prudent consideration of vocation.

verses.text: This is what I mean, brothers and sisters: the time is short. From now on, those who have wives should live as though they had none,
verses.comment: Paul points to the urgency and eschatological focus of the Christian life; the coming Kingdom transforms priorities.

verses.text: those who weep, as though they did not weep; those who rejoice, as though they did not rejoice; those who buy, as though they did not possess;
verses.comment: Worldly joys and sorrows are passing; Christians are called to live detached from earthly things, focusing on heavenly promises.

verses.text: those who use the world, as though not engrossed in it. For the present form of this world is passing away.
verses.comment: Here, Paul affirms the fleeting nature of worldly affairs, encouraging spiritual detachment for the sake of the Kingdom.

verses.text: I want you to be free from anxieties. The unmarried man is concerned with the things of the Lord, how to please the Lord.
verses.comment: Celibacy offers undivided devotion. The spiritual meaning points to single-hearted commitment to service and prayer.

verses.text: But the married man is concerned with the things of the world, how to please his wife,
verses.comment: Marriage involves real, necessary concerns—this is a holy vocation, distinct from but complementary to celibate service.

verses.text: and his interests are divided. And the unmarried woman or virgin is concerned with the things of the Lord, aspiring to be holy in body and spirit. But the married woman is concerned with the things of the world, how to please her husband.
verses.comment: 'Holy in body and spirit' stresses that both physical and spiritual dimensions matter, reflecting a high theology of human nature.

verses.text: I am saying this for your benefit—not to place a restraint upon you, but to lead you to a fitting and undistracted devotion to the Lord.
verses.comment: Paul elevates undivided devotion as an ideal, not a law; freedom of discernment is vital for spiritual growth.

verses.text: If anyone thinks he is not behaving appropriately toward his virgin, and if she is past her youth and it must be so, let him do what he wishes; he does not sin—let them marry.
verses.comment: Ancient customs around betrothal are referenced. Marriage is not sinful; the Church has always honored it as a good.

verses.text: But he who stands firm in his heart, having no necessity, but has control over his own will and has resolved in his own heart to keep his virgin, he will do well.
verses.comment: Voluntary celibacy is commended as a special calling; spiritual self-control is esteemed highly in the tradition.

verses.text: So then he who gives his virgin in marriage does well; and he who does not give her in marriage does better.
verses.comment: Celibacy as a higher calling reflects a spiritual interpretation of Christian life, yet marriage remains holy and good.

verses.text: A wife is bound to her husband as long as he lives. But if her husband dies, she is free to marry whomever she wishes, only in the Lord.
verses.comment: 'Only in the Lord' restricts remarriage to believers, maintaining the spiritual integrity of the marriage bond.

verses.text: But in my judgment, she is happier if she remains as she is. And I believe I too have the Spirit of God.
verses.comment: Paul, guided by the Holy Spirit, advocates joyful discernment, suggesting that wisdom and interior freedom are vital for the Christian journey.
